Dear JILL SCHREUDER:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Mark Hunter, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000858
Special Investigation Intake Date: 07/15/2025
License #: CB410245705
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: JILL SCHREUDER
Chief Administrator: JILL SCHREUDER
Agency Name: CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN -
GR
Agency Address: 40 JEFFERSON AVE
GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49503-4304
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/19/2027
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
7/17/2025 10:44 AM Phone Special Investigation Initiation
7/17/2025 2:45 PM Phone Interview
7/28/2025 3:00 PM Email Documentation received or sent

9/29/2025 2:45 PM Phone Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals and be primarily responsible for the
1

development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not doing enough to protect Youth A.
Investigation Interviews:
I interviewed Complainant by phone on 7/17/2025. Complainant
stated Youth A has had a number of truancies/AWOL while under
the supervision of this agency. Complainant stated Youth A is at a
greater risk of harm during these truancies/AWOL episodes.
Complainant stated Youth A needs to be in a residential
placement to minimize the risk of truancy. I interviewed
Complainant by phone again on 7/23/2025 and Complainant
reported Youth A had truanted from Youth A's placement at the
Osceola Youth Center. Complainant reported no further concerns
on agency not protecting Youth A.
I interviewed Foster Care Director by phone on 7/17/2025.
Foster Care Director described Youth A as a constant truancy risk.
Foster Care Director stated Youth A had been placed for a period
of time with Relative A. Foster Care Director stated Youth A has
expressed no interest in being placed with Relative A again. I
interviewed Foster Care Director by phone again on 9/16/2025.
Foster Care Director stated Youth A is currently in a residential
placement effective 9/08/2025. I requested Foster Care Director
to submit additional information related to the care and
supervision of Youth A by this agency. This information was
submitted and received 07/28/2025 and a summary is provided in
the Documents Reviewed section of this report. Foster Care
Director stated the agency followed their truancy/AWOL protocols
when Youth A truanted to facilitate a recovery of Youth A as soon
as possible.
I interviewed Chief Administrator by phone on 09/26/2025.
Chief Administrator provided contact information for the foster
care worker of Youth A.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker by phone on 09/26/2025.
Foster Care Worker stated she has been the foster care worker
for Youth A for approximately 1 year. Foster Care Worker
confirmed Youth A is presently in a residential placement. Foster
Care Worker stated she thought some of the reasons for Youth A
truanting were related to attachment/separation and mental health
issues of Youth A. Foster Care Worker stated Youth A never
2

reported feeling unsafe or having concern for safety related issues
as a reason for any truancies.
I interviewed Youth A by phone on 09/29/2025. Youth A reported
Youth A is currently in a residential program. Youth A stated a
previous residential placement was helpful but is uncertain if the
current residential placement will be helpful. Youth A indicated a
possible permanency plan as independent living or placement with
Youth A’s stepmother. Youth A stated Youth A felt safe in Youth
A's current placement and previous placements.
Documents Reviewed:
I reviewed the case management information submitted by Foster
Care Director on 07/28/2025. This information included activities
associated with the AWOL incidents of Youth A, placement
history, safety plans and attempts to maintain placements, and
services that were provided to meet the needs of Youth A. A
summary of the information submitted at the time of this request is
as follows:
• Agency efforts during every incident Youth A went AWOL
o Youth A was AWOL on the following dates: 4/23/25-
5/6/25, 6/1/25-7/4/25, 7/8/25-7/10/25, 7/22/25-
Current.
o A CCWM IR, WMPC IR, and DCWL IR have been
completed.
o AWOL protocol/checklist has been followed; a pick
up order filed and Youth A entered on LEIN, the
biological parents and GAL were notified, a DHS 710
and DHS 3198A were completed, and the National
Center for Missing and Exploited Children was
notified.
o All AWOL efforts to locate are entered as social work
contacts in MiSACWIS and labeled as such.
• List of each placement for Youth A and what efforts agency
made to maintain placements including FTMS, TDMS,
Safety Plans, Visits, and services
• List of services
o Youth A has had multiple stays at Helen DeVos for
mental health assessments, the majority of these
occurred after each of her returns from AWOL.
o Youth A has been working with Catholic Charities
West Michigan Enhanced Foster Care and
Behavioral Specialist services throughout her time in
foster care. She participated in these services from
02/14/2023 through 05/15/2023, 06/30/2023 through
07/23/2024, and 12/21/2024 through 06/01/2025.
3

o During Youth A’s recent placement with her adult
half-sister, she was set up in counseling services
with the Big Rapids Community Mental Health
(CMH). The services just briefly started as Youth A
was only there for just over three weeks. Youth A
has been discharged from this service as she no
longer resides in that county.
o While placed in the unrelated foster home in Berrien
County, Youth A had begun working with Berrien’s
Community Mental Health program, Riverwood. She
qualified for weekly home-based counseling
services. These services started in early March of
2025.
o Prior to that, Youth A was in a residential, Gail’s
House, from 08/07/2024 through 12/21/2024. At
Gail’s House, Youth A had medication reviews with a
psychiatrist, nursing services, individual therapy,
group therapy, PBS (positive behavior skills),
TARGET Group (identifying triggers and alarm
reactions), skills group (teaching life skills),
educational time, physical activity, structured group
activities, positive peer interaction, and 24/7 direct
care from staff.
o Prior to that, Youth A was admitted to Forest View
for inpatient treatment from 7/23/25-8/7/25.
o Prior to her stay in residential, Youth A was placed
with the same unrelated foster home in Berrien
County where she received services through
Riverwood Center which started 07/10/2024 and she
qualified for home-based counseling, psychiatric
services, and WRAP services.
o Prior to that, while Youth A was in Kent County, she
was working with Arbor Circle, but was not in Kent
County long enough to get counseling services
established. She completed an intake with Arbor
Circle on 05/14/2024 however this service ended for
Youth A on 07/08/2024 due to her moving from the
county.
o Prior to that, Youth A was working with Big Rapids
CMH and was receiving home-based counseling,
psychiatry, and WRAP services. Services with Big
Rapids CMH were active from 11/06/2023 through
04/08/2024.
o Prior to this, Youth A was working with D. A.
Blodgett for Home-Based services from 09/25/2023
through 10/03/2023.
4

o Prior to that, Youth A was admitted to Cedar Creek
for inpatient treatment from 9/8/23-9/18/23.
o Prior to that, Youth A was admitted to Forest View
for inpatient treatment from 8/7/23-8/16/23.
o Prior to this, Youth A was in D.A. Blodgett’s Trauma
Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT)
from 02/20/2023 through 09/25/2023.
• MISACWIS placement record for Youth A was reviewed.
This record indicated Youth A has been placed in licensed
foster homes, relative caregiver placements, enhanced
foster care placements, hospital, AWOL, CCI’s, and
detention consistent to what Foster Care Director reported.
• I reviewed documentation in MISACWIS that provided
verification of the services reported in Foster Care
Director’s report.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with the rule per the interviews
that were completed and the records that were reviewed. The
agency provided a number of services to meet the needs of Youth
A and made reasonable efforts to maintain the placements of
Youth A. The agency facilitated a variety of placements in
attempts to serve Youth A and keep Youth A safe.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
10/01/2025
______________________________________
Mark Hunter Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
